question: You are a coding expert. Please use your professional knowledge to generate accurate and professional responses. Be sure to ensure that the code you generate is executable for demonstration purposes. Could you help me design and create a personal website homepage? It would primarily be used for sharing photos, text, and videos within a small circle of family and friends. The purpose is to maintain and strengthen connections and emotional bonds between loved ones scattered across different regions, and to accumulate and showcase information about interactive activities among family and friends.

checklist.title: Is the personal homepage core functionality fully implemented?
checklist.description: Review whether the code accurately implements photo, text, and video sharing capabilities through HTML/CSS/JavaScript, including file upload handling, content display grid/list views, and basic CRUD operations for posts. Score 0 if core sharing functionality is missing, 5 if only basic text/image sharing is implemented, and 10 if multimedia sharing with proper preview and organization is fully included.

checklist.title: Is the family circle interaction system properly designed?
checklist.description: Check whether the implementation includes user authentication for family members, comment/reaction systems, and privacy controls for content visibility within the circle. Evaluate if there's a proper user management system distinguishing family roles. Deduct 5 points if no user authentication exists, and 3 points if privacy controls are inadequate. The full score is 10 points.

checklist.title: Is content organization and timeline management effectively structured?
checklist.description: Evaluate whether the homepage uses effective content categorization (albums, events, chronological timeline) and search/filter capabilities. Check if there's proper content archiving and easy navigation through historical posts. Deduct 5 points if content organization is chaotic or lacks categorization. Check whether memory preservation features like anniversary reminders or milestone highlighting are implemented. The full score is 10 points.

checklist.title: Is cross-device compatibility and data persistence properly handled?
checklist.description: Check whether the code includes responsive design for mobile/tablet access, local storage or cloud storage integration for content persistence, and offline viewing capabilities. Evaluate if family members can access content seamlessly across different devices. Deduct 5 points if mobile responsiveness is poor, and 3 points if data persistence mechanisms are missing. Give 10 points if fully optimized for family sharing scenarios.

checklist.title: Is the code robust?
checklist.description: Evaluate whether the code can handle common abnormal situations (such as large file uploads, unsupported media formats, network interruption, browser compatibility issues, etc.) and provide friendly error prompts or recovery mechanisms. Code with strong robustness should be able to effectively handle these edge cases, giving 10 points. If the robustness is average, give 5 points, and if no exceptions are handled, give 0 points.

checklist.title: Are there any innovative features that enhance family bonding?
checklist.description: Check whether the code includes thoughtful features that strengthen family connections (e.g., 1. Automatic photo tagging and face recognition 2. Family event calendar integration 3. Memory lane random photo displays 4. Voice message attachments 5. Location-based content grouping). Add 3 points for each practical innovative feature implemented (maximum 10 points).

checklist.title: Are there any redundant features?
checklist.description: Strictly check three types of redundancy: 1. Redundant implementation of similar functions (e.g., multiple upload mechanisms coexisting) 2. Function modules unrelated to family sharing (e.g., e-commerce components, gaming features) 3. Overly complex effects that slow down content loading (e.g., heavy 3D animations, excessive parallax effects). Deduct 3 points for each redundancy found, and directly deduct 10 points if the core sharing functions are interfered with by redundant code.

checklist.title: Does the code have engineering quality?
checklist.description: Review modular design (such as separating content management/UI components/data layers), performance optimization for media loading, and scalable architecture. Deduct 5 points if global state pollution is found or component structure is poorly organized; deduct 5 points if media optimization is missing (lazy loading, compression); deduct 5 points if the code lacks maintainability. The full score is 10 points.

checklist.title: Does the interface design create a warm, family-friendly atmosphere?
checklist.description: Evaluate whether the overall design creates an intimate, welcoming environment suitable for family sharing: 1) Warm color palette that evokes comfort and closeness 2) Intuitive navigation that's accessible to all age groups 3) Clean, uncluttered layout that highlights content over interface 4) Proper typography hierarchy for readability (body font â‰¥ 16px for older family members). Deduct 3 points for each element that feels cold or commercial, 5 points for poor accessibility for elderly users, and 5 points for cluttered layouts that distract from content. The full score is 10 points.

checklist.title: Is the user experience optimized for non-technical family members?
checklist.description: Judge whether the interactions are designed for users of varying technical abilities: 1) Drag-and-drop file uploads with clear visual feedback 2) One-click sharing with intuitive icons 3) Simple content organization that doesn't require technical knowledge 4) Fast loading times for media content (images load within 2 seconds). Deduct 5 points for each confusing interaction flow, 3 points for slow media loading, and 5 points if elderly or less tech-savvy users would struggle with basic operations. The full score is 10 points.
